(XY)^Z Part II

Bruce J. Swihart

2025-05-16

Source: vignettes/articles/xy_to_the_z_part_ii.Rmd
xy_to_the_z_part_ii.Rmd

IN PROGRESS

So far we have considered cases where the alpha for X and Y are the same and how multiplying (log(1/X)+log(1/Y)) by Z allows one to recover the original distribution of log(1/X) (equivalently, log(1/Y)). However, if αx≠αy\alpha_x \neq \alpha_y, multiplying (log(1/X)+log(1/Y)) by a uniform would not recover the distribution for either log(1/X) or log(1/Y) – it would be a distribution “in-between” those two distributions – but not an Exponential with an alpha between αx\alpha_x and αy\alpha_y. We consider this “unequal alpha” as a bonus case below.

Bonus: Unequal alpha cases

Firstly, one may want to consult Wikipedia.

  • Wikipedia Sum of Two Independent Exponential Random Variables

So, in this setup, there is no one distribution to recover since αx≠αy\alpha_x \neq \alpha_y, so trying different distributions for ZZ leads to different blends of the X,Y distributions for the quantity Z(log(1/X)+log(1/Y)).

Z distributed as U(0,1)

  • Z∼Z \sim U(0,1)
  • magenta density
    • fw(w)=−mn(Γ(0,mw)−Γ(0,nw))m−nf_w(w) = - \frac{mn \left( \Gamma(0,mw) - \Gamma(0,nw)\right)}{ m-n } where W=Z(log1X+log1Y)W = Z \left( \log \frac{1}{X} + \log \frac{1}{Y} \right), m=αx\alpha_x, n=αy\alpha_y
    • Γ(.,.)\Gamma(.,.) is incomplete Gamma function.

  • While the computed quantity is not exponential, one can see it is a concentration of the convolution and that it is kind of “in-between” the two component distributions.

Z distributed as Inverse-Gamma(alpha, beta)

  • Z∼Z \sim Inverse-Gamma(αz\alpha_z, βz\beta_z)

  • gold density

    • fw(w)=mnn−mβzαzΓ(αz+1)Γ(αz)(1(mw+βz)αz+1−1(nw+βz)αz+1)f_w(w) = \frac{mn}{ n-m }\frac{\beta_z^{\alpha_z}\Gamma(\alpha_z + 1)}{ \Gamma(\alpha_z) } \left( \frac{1}{ \left(mw+\beta_z\right)^{\alpha_z +1}}-\frac{1}{ \left(nw+\beta_z\right)^{\alpha_z +1}} \right) where W=Z(log1X+log1Y)W = Z \left( \log \frac{1}{X} + \log \frac{1}{Y} \right), m=αx\alpha_x, n=αy\alpha_y.

  • While the computed quantity is not exponential, one can see it is a concentration of the convolution and that it is kind of “in-between” the two component distributions.

Z distributed as Pareto

  • Z∼Z \sim Pareto(xm=1x_m=1,αm=1\alpha_m=1) (where 1/Z ~ U(0,1))

  • magenta density:

    • fw(w)=n2(1−exp−mw(1+mw))−m2(1−exp−nw(1+nw))mn(n−m)w2f_w(w) = \frac{n^2 (1-\exp^{-mw}(1+mw)) - m^2 (1-\exp^{-nw}(1+nw))}{ mn(n-m)w^2 } where W=Z(log1X+log1Y)W = Z \left( \log \frac{1}{X} + \log \frac{1}{Y} \right), m=αx\alpha_x, n=αy\alpha_y.

  • What is the opposite of “concentration” – bleeding out? Multiplying the convolution by a random number bigger than 1 disperses it.
